text: hello i am yuri the company with aws
solutions architecture
today i will show you how you can use
the new aws principle is aws service
global condition key
to safely grant access to your
authorized users
expected network locations and aws
services together
when you are storing data in aws cloud
you are looking for a proper data
security controls
such as identity and access management
network security
and encryption often when you work with
sensitive data
you'd like to assure that only
authorized users can access your data
but they can access it only from known
approved locations
for example you may want to allow access
to your s3 buckets only from corporate
network
or from specific amazon vpc
also you want to make sure that the data
is restricted to trusted identities
such as your authorized corporate users
to satisfy these requirements you can
use such aws im global condition keys as
aws source vpc or aws source ip
locking down access to your s3 buckets
in s3 bucket policy
to ensure that only trusted identities
can access your data
you may limit access to users with your
aws organization
by using aws principle org id
restriction
at the same time you want to use aws
services
some of which are accessing your buckets
using their own identities
and from outside of your network
locations
such as aws cloud trail or amazon macy
for example
if you limit access to your s3 buckets
to your organization ip addresses range
you are essentially preventing these
services from accessing your buckets
today i will show you how to address
this with the new iem global condition
key
aws principle is aws service which
allows to restrict
access to your aws resources such as s3
buckets from a trusted network
locations while simultaneously safely
granting access to aws services
to illustrate usage of aws principle is
aws service global condition key
let's go over couple of scenarios let's
go to the aws management console
and first take a look at the example
where i allow
aws cloud trail to write aws api
calls logs to my s3 bucket
as far as you may know cloudtrail allows
me to continuously monitor
and log aws api actions across
my aws infrastructure with aws
cloudtrail
i can create a trail enabling ongoing
delivery of
api event log files to an amazon s3
bucket that i specify
now let's say that my organization
security standards require limiting
access to
all s3 buckets including the cloudtrail
logs bucket
only to the organization's network to
satisfy this requirement
i go to the cloudtrail destination s3
bucket
and add a statement to the bucket policy
where i deny
access to mystery bucket from ip
addresses
other than my organization's ones
when a principal makes a request to aws
aws gathers the request information into
the request
context then we use conditions in the
policy statement to compare keys
in the request context with the key
value that we specify
in the policy this condition will be met
if the source ap address of the
principal making a call
we get this source ap from the request
context is not the one
i specify here i don't want to lock
myself
out so for the demo purposes i'll use my
current ap
address in this policy due to cloudtrail
is accessing this bucket from ap
addresses that do not belong to my
organization's ap address range
this policy breaks cloudtrail logs
delivery
if i go to the cloudtrail console you
can see that cloudtrail
reports login error for my trail
i'll not fix this policy here instead i
go back to the s3 console
choose cloudtrail destination bucket and
add another condition to the policy
that will exclude aws service principles
from this deny statement
i use boolean condition here that
compares the request context key to true
or false
this part of the condition will be met
if principle that makes a call
is not an aws service if policy has
multiple condition operators
or if i put multiple keys in the same
condition operator
like here they are evaluated using
logical and
so entire condition will be met when the
source ap
address of a calling principle is not my
source ap
and the calling principle is not aws
service
in this case request will be denied
with this updated policy aws cloudtrail
will be able to write
log files to the bucket while on non-aws
service principles
will be able to access this bucket only
from
organizations network
let's check this in the cloudtrail
console and you can see that cloudtrail
login has been restored
to assure this policy works as desired
let's make a couple of api
calls using aws management console
checking the status of the ec2 instances
running
in this region on this account
in a few minutes a new cloud trail log
file has been delivered to the s3 bucket
let's also try to list s3 objects from
my amazon workspaces remote
desktop which has ap address different
from what i allowed in the s3 bucket
policy
and see that access has been denied
note that in this example we don't grant
but constrain
the permissions granted by aws im
identity based policies
or appropriate allow statements in the
s3 bucket policy
we will see this in more details in the
next example
let's take a look at another scenario
when amazon macy
is delivering sensitive data discovery
results to the s3 bucket
amazon mac uses machine learning and
pattern matching
to detect sensitive data stored in
amazon s3
to ensure long-term retention of macy's
sensitive data discovery results
i configured the s3 bucket for my
repository
within 30 days of enabling macy and macy
stores the sensitive data discovery
results
in json line files writing them to the
s3 bucket
sgzip files if we take a look
at this tree bucket macy uses to write
the results too
its policy has a number of statements
allowing
aws principal macy to put objects and to
get bucket location
now following my organization security
requirements
i'd like to limit access to this bucket
only to the principals
aws users groups or roles that belong to
my
aws organization
i can add the corresponding deny
statement limiting any access to this
bucket to the principles belong to my
aws organization's accounts using aws
principle org id global condition key
this would block amazon macy as well due
to macy uses its own principle to access
my s3 bucket
to allow macy writing the sensitive
discovery results to this bucket
i'll use aws principle is aws service
global condition key again
to allow aws services to access this
bucket
let's try accessing this bucket from aws
cli
using temporary credentials while
signing into my aws account
with aws sso
i am signing in with my external
identity provider user
and you can see i can list the bucket
content successfully
now let's say i mistakenly granted
access to this bucket
to the sandbox account outside of my aws
organization in general i can grant
cross account access to my aws resources
using cross account iam roles
alternatively
i can use resource-based policies if the
specific aws service supports them
for these three buckets i can also use
access control lists or accols
to grant access across accounts in this
example i have
access granted to my sandbox account
using the bucket accol
now in my cli window i'll use another
aws profile
configured with iem user credentials for
my sandbox account
when i'm trying to list the account
content my
access has been denied as far as you can
see
even occl allows access from an internal
account
principle org id key condition in the
bucket policy blocks it
also i've just had macy's job finished
here
and you can see it delivered new
findings successfully
at the end i wanted to address the
question i've been recently asked
can i apply this protection for my
entire aws organization
when i establish my data perimeter
or in other words can i use this key
in the organization's service control
policies or
scps to answer this question
let's clarify first that scps control
how identities that belong to your aws
organization's accounts
use aws services and resources
scps do not have impact on the
identities
outside of your aws organization's
accounts
so if you granted cross account access
to your resource to the account
outside of your organization or you
granted access to the aws service that
uses its own
principle to access your resources such
as
aws cloudtrail or amazon macy your aws
organization's scps are not applicable
in these cases therefore
while you can use such aws global
condition
keys as aws source vpc or
aws source ip in your scp deny
statements conditions
these deny statements have no impact on
the aws services principles
and it would not make sense to use aws
principle is
aws service global condition key in your
scp
you've just seen how you can use the new
aws principle
is aws service global condition key to
simplify resource-based policies
while limiting access to trusted
identities and expected networks
at the same time granted access to aws
services
that use their own service principles
from
outside of your network locations
thank you for watching it was yuri the
company with aws solutions architecture
